question: Question_04_(e)
statement:
Consider a network arranged in the shape of an octahedron as in this
diagram:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MATH307_April_2012_Question_04.png}
\end{description}

The nodes have been labeled with the large numbers and 3 of the edges
(resistors) have been given orientations and labeled with small numbers.
Assume all resistances are equal to 1. Let \emph{D} be the incidence
matrix (for some choice of labeling and arrows for the remaining edges)
and let \emph{L} be the Laplacian.

\textbf{(e)} It seems reasonable to conjecture that the effective
resistance between nodes 1 and 6 would remain unchanged if removed the
resistors between 2 and 3, 3 and 4, 4 and 5, 5 and 2. Explain how you
could use MATLAB/Octave to test this conjecture. Assume that \emph{L}
has been defined in MATLAB/Octave.
sols:
To find the effective resistance between two nodes, you would have to
swap the 1st and sixth columns to the 1 and 2 positions inside the
Laplacian matrix. You would then break up this Laplacian matrix into a
block matrix\[L = \begin{bmatrix}
A & B^{T} \\
B & C 
\end{bmatrix}\] where $A$ will be a 2x2 matrix.

You would then find the voltage to current map (A.K.A Schur$^{\prime}$s
complement), matrix S whose equation is\[S = A - B^{T} C^{-1} B\]

Then, after solving for S, the effective resistance would be the
reciprocal of the 1st entry of matrix S.

MATLAB CODE:

\texttt{~~~\%nodes~n~and~m~position}\\\texttt{~~~n~=~1;}\\\texttt{~~~m~=~6;}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%find~the~size~of~the~matrix~L}\\\texttt{~~~lenL~=~length(L);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%swap~nodes~n~and~m~to~the~1st~and~2nd~position~in~the~Laplacian~matrix}\\\texttt{~~~swap~=~{[}n,~m,~1:(n-1),~(n+1):(m-1),~(m+1):lenL{]};}\\\texttt{~~~L~=~L(swap,~swap);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%compute~matrix~S~which~is~the~voltage~to~current~map~(Schur's~complement).}\\\texttt{~~~A~=~L((1:2),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~B~=~L((3:lenL),~(1:2));}\\\texttt{~~~C~=~L((3:lenL),~(3:lenL));}\\\texttt{~~~S~=~A~-~(B}$^{\prime}$\texttt{~*~C}\textsuperscript{\texttt{(}}\texttt{-1)~*~B);}\\\texttt{~~~}\\\texttt{~~~\%finds~the~effective~resistance~which~is~the~first~entry~of~S.}\\\texttt{~~~r~=~1/S(1,1);}

You could run this for the 2 different Laplacian matrices to find the
effective resistance for each and compare them to confirm the conjecture
is correct.
